idCitation.resTitle: South Carolina Rail, Road, and Aviation Noise

citRespParty.rpOrgName: Office of the Assistant Secretary for Research and Technology/Bureau of Transportation Statistics, Office of Spatial Analysis and Visualization

dataIdInfo.idAbs: The National Transportation Noise Map dataset is current as of July 2022, published by Volpe and the Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS), and part of U.S. Department of Transportation (USDOT)/ BTS' National Transportation Atlas Database (NTAD). This dataset is developed using a 24-hr equivalent sound level (LEQ, denoted by LAeq) noise metrics. The results are A-weighted noise levels that represent the approximate average noise energy due to transportation noise sources over the 24-hour period at the defined receptors. This map includes simplified noise modeling and is intended for the tracking of trends, it should not be used to evaluate noise levels in individual locations and/or at specific times.
dataIdInfo.idPurp: The dataset provides noise data to facilitate the tracking of trends in transportation-related noise. This dataset includes results from simplified noise modeling methods and should not be used to evaluate noise levels in individual locations. For a full description of methodologies and assumptions visit the Bureau of Transportation Statistics website and search for the National Transportation Noise Mapping Tool.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: Acknowledgement of the Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) and the Volpe National Transportation Systems Center (Volpe).

Consts.useLimit: NTAD datasets are intended for public usage and are not for sale or resale. The National Transportation Noise Map and associated data were developed for national level analysis and includes simplified noise modeling. It is intended for the tracking of trends and should not be used to evaluate noise levels in individual locations or at specific times. There are potential differences in the data sources and the complexity of the models used for noise modeling depending on type of analysis. The term "potential to be exposed" is used because there are several conservative assumptions that go into the analysis. If any one of those assumptions were to change, the noise exposure numbers could also change. For example, the documentation states "Shielding is not considered (i.e. attenuation due to barriers and terrain are not considered)"; for areas that have shielding, the noise levels may be overestimated. The average implies that sound levels could be both higher and lower, depending upon time of day, season of the year, etc. Additionally, sounds from transportation sources other than aviation, road, and passenger and freight rail (e.g. buses and maritime) as well as non-transportation sources are not considered. Sounds from things such as construction sites, rock quarries, power plants, etc., could dampen some of the transportation noise.
